node.title: 'We get nothing' but lower speed limit: Opposition to SH5 change gathers pace
node.description: Regional leaders in Hawke's Bay have decided to oppose the decision to drop the speed limit on the highway between Napier and Taupō.

node.title: USA hockey star Brianna Decker injured in 5-2 win to open Olympics
node.description: Now the Americans must forge ahead — likely without their top center — in their bid to become the first U.S. squad to win consecutive titles.

node.title: Planned 2degrees and Orcon Group merger taking shape before deal settled, approved
node.description: Vocus Communications chief executive Mark Callander will lead the merged company to be known as 2degrees.

node.title: 'There will be life after Covid' - PM reveals decision for NZ's border reopening
node.description: Jacinda Ardern has outlined the details about when New Zealand's borders will reopen.

node.title: Afghans still stranded despite court ruling allowing them into NZ
node.description: Community Law Aotearoa blames the government for blocking scores of people from getting the official help that is available to other Afghans with visas.

node.title: From rock bottom to new horizons - a new beginning for Tauranga CBD
node.description: Tauranga's broken-hearted CBD, once littered with for lease signs in shop windows has turned a page with the opening of a $200 million development.

node.title: White Ferns World Cup squad named
node.description: An experienced core and a sprinkling of youthful exuberance will represent New Zealand at the upcoming ICC Women's Cricket World Cup.

node.title: Kiwis rejoice in border plan, but it's 'too little, too late' for some
node.description: Some New Zealanders have jumped at the chance to reunite with loved ones and travel overseas, after learning the country's borders will slowly creak open this year. Audio

node.title: ISIS leader blows himself up during U.S. special ops raid in Syria
node.description: Biden praised the troops who carried out the raid "to protect the American people and our Allies," and said the ISIS leader killed his own family members with his bomb.

node.title: Gov. Kristi Noem's abortion ban proposal stifled by GOP lawmakers
node.description: "D.C. does stuff like that, not South Dakota," Governor Kristi Noem said after lawmakers declined to consider her proposal.

node.title: MacKenzie Scott donates $133.5 million to educational nonprofit
node.description: The donation could help millions of students who have had their education impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

node.title: With post office closures, small towns feel loss of community
node.description: Over the years, new innovations have chipped away at the postal service's business, putting its future in doubt.

node.title: Tesla recalls 817,000 vehicles with faulty seat-belt chime
node.description: Audible alert may fail to signal driver that their seat belt is unbuckled, increasing risk of injury or death in crash.

node.title: Winter storm blasts snow, freezing rain and sleet across U.S.
node.description: The storm system has placed more than 100 million Americans under winter weather alerts, and over 4,000 flights had already been canceled by Thursday morning.

node.title: U.S. Army to discharge soldiers who refuse COVID vaccine
node.description: The Army says 96% of active-duty soldiers have already completed vaccination against COVID-19.

node.title: Stocks tumble amid Facebook's record $220 billion rout
node.description: Social media giant shed 25% of its value in early Thursday trading after reporting its first decline in users.

node.title: Kim back on a white horse in North Korea's latest propaganda video
node.description: The production touts Kim Jong Un's economic leadership, but doesn't mention his 7 recent missile tests in breach of U.N. sanctions.

node.title: Fewer Americans apply for jobless aid as Omicron wave recedes
node.description: Weekly unemployment claims are again falling as job market bounces back from Omicron hit.
